statement.text: The radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula (Brescia-Cimino fistula) is the preferred initial dialysis access, anastomosing the radial artery to the cephalic vein at the wrist, offering excellent longevity and low complication rates.
statement.formal: Location: Distal forearm, wrist level; Anastomosis: Radial artery to cephalic vein; Maturation: 4-6 weeks; Patency: 60-70% at 1 year, 40-50% at 5 years; First choice per KDOQI guidelines

explanation.intuition: We connect an artery to a vein at the wrist, turning the vein into a thick, high-flow blood vessel that can be repeatedly accessed with dialysis needles. Starting at the wrist preserves options higher up the arm if this fistula fails.
explanation.key_insight: Fistula First - the radiocephalic fistula is the gold standard for dialysis access because of longevity and lowest complication rates.
explanation.technical_details: The radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula (AVF) was first described by Brescia and Cimino in 1966. It anastomoses the radial artery to the cephalic vein at the wrist using end-to-side or side-to-side technique. Advantages include preserving proximal access sites, low steal syndrome risk, and excellent long-term patency. The 'fistula first' initiative promotes autogenous access over grafts and catheters. Preoperative vein mapping is essential to confirm adequate cephalic vein diameter (>2.5 mm) and patency.
common_misconceptions: All patients can have radiocephalic fistula - FALSE, requires adequate vein (>2.5 mm)
Fistulas work immediately - FALSE, need 4-6 weeks to mature
Wrist fistula is only for young patients - FALSE, applicable to many patients
Side-to-side is always better than end-to-side - FALSE, both are acceptable

clinical_exam: Prior IV access sites and damage

immediate: Avoid BP measurements or blood draws in access arm

maturation.rule_of_6s: Flow >600 mL/min, diameter >6 mm, depth <6 mm

vs_other_access.vs_brachiocephalic: Lower steal risk, preserves proximal options

definition.@value: Arteriovenous fistula at the wrist anastomosing radial artery to cephalic vein, the preferred initial dialysis access.

diagnosis: Assessment of central veins if history of catheters

sources.reference: KDOQI Clinical Practice Guidelines for Vascular Access
Brescia MJ, Cimino JE et al. NEJM 1966 - original description

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy and surgical technique of radiocephalic fistula
Explain preoperative evaluation including vein mapping
Apply the 'Rule of 6s' for fistula maturation assessment
clinical_pearls: Fistula First - radiocephalic is gold standard, preserves proximal options
Vein diameter ≥2.5 mm predicts maturation success
Rule of 6s: Flow >600 mL/min, diameter >6 mm, depth <6 mm
Maturation takes 4-12 weeks - plan ahead before dialysis start
Never use the access arm for BP, blood draws, or IVs
